title: Clarke sets bar high at Treasury
text:
But Clarke insisted this was not an example of CEO getting out when growth has peaked.

Clarke and his successor Tim Ford, who is currently Treasury’s chief operating officer, said repeatedly that Treasury’s best years are ahead of it, and pointed to a number of key initiatives that are either in train or still to come that will deliver the next phase of the wine group’s growth.

These include the new distribution model that has been rolled out across the key North American market, planned changes to distribution in China that should boost cash flow and sales, and the accelerating growth of Treasury’s business in France, where it will spend $135 million this financial year to buy vineyards and production infrastructure in the Bordeaux region.

“I am absolutely envious that I am not going to be here in three years times, or five years time,” Clarke says.

“I feel like a proud father – I feel upset I am not going to be part of it, though.”

Clarke’s focus as an adviser – and probably for the next 12 months ass well, given Ford runs Treasury’s day-to-day operations – will be on deals.

As Clarke said a few weeks ago at the investor day, the business is in discussions with a number of parties as it looks to increase its portfolio of luxury wines. Having Clarke around for two years will mean Treasury won’t have to rush any of these negotiations.

Clarke even said he’s willing to stay on as London-based adviser for longer, if chairman Paul Rayner and Ford want him.

The prickliness on the call came from Clarke’s clear distaste for any suggestion that his regular sales of stock were a sign of a lack of confidence in the business.

He said he only ever sold shares to cover tax liabilities and said he wanted to provide “air cover” for Ford and other executives, who would likely have to sell shares in the future given Treasury’s growth, and should not be subjected to the “ridiculous amount of repeated media coverage” that has accompanied his sell downs.

The fall in Treasury’s share price on Monday is, of course, reinforcement of how much investors love him.

And given he’s taken Treasury from basket case to market darling since arriving in March 2014 – and taking the share price from $3.50 to $17 over that period – it’s not hard to understand the depth of feeling.

While Clarke is a clear believer in the magic of wine – when Chanticleer sat down with him in Melbourne last week, he praised his wine makers as the company’s real rock stars – his real legacy will be shifting Treasury away from the boom-and-bust mentality of a cyclical agricultural business and into the realms of a consumer brands business.

By shifting from the traditional industry model of owning huge numbers of vines to a model of leasing and contracting two-thirds of Treasury’s grapes, Clarke has boosted Treasury’s return on capital employed from 6.8 per cent to a sector-leading 14.9 per cent.

By planning the release of vintages over five years, and taking a multi-regional approach to wine-making – producing Penfolds-branded wines in California’s Napa Valley and France, for example – Clarke has been able to tilt Treasury’s portfolio towards luxury and so-called “masstige” wines – anything above $10 a bottle. This has seen the group’s EBIT margin double over the past five years.

By aggressively shifting in Asia, and China particularly, Clarke has boosted group EBIT from $225 million to $663 million between the 2015 and 2019 financial years.

The pace of change has been impressive and, as Clarke admitted on Monday, occasionally problematic; he said mistakes had been made around the leadership team, for example.

But Clarke will leave in 12 months with an impressive platform, and some big growth initiatives underway. The bar is set high for Ford.
description: Given Michael Clarke has taken Treasury from basket case to market darling since arriving in March 2014 – and taking the share price from $3.50 to $17 over that period – it’s understandable how much investors love him.
